name: OWASP BE - Component Analysis vs SCA (by Steven Springett)
description:
On October 21st, we have scheduled Steven Springett with Component Analysis vs SCA - How SBOMs are the driving force for change.

This chapter meeting is part of a series of virtual chapter meetings (every 3rd Thursday of the month).

Our chapter meetings are open for everyone, and attendance is free of charge. We ask you to register on Meetup in order to provide you with last-minute updates, if needed. Registered attendees can join via Zoom, and ask questions to the speakers.

More info on this series of chapter meetings or on the Belgium OWASP chapter can be found at https://owasp.org/www-chapter-belgium/ .

name: “Put your White Hat on!” and join us
description:
Put your White Hat on!” and join us.

OWASP (The Open We Application Security Project) chapter in Cluj presents an open online event for the specialists in Information Security in Cluj, as well as anyone interested or aspiring to a career in this domain.

We’re building up a Cybersecurity Community and there’s no better way than gathering all experts and future experts to a first event that marks this beginning.

Register today to find out hands-on information about how can you prevent and manage Information Security breaches and incidents, learn best practices and more.

Find below the speakers and topics of the meetup:

Romeo Andreica, Information Security Engineer arobs
The Impact of Day 0 in Informations Security:
• The information attacks in the contexts of Day-Zero vulnerabilities
• The incidence of these type of attacks in the prezent context and remote work
• Identification, evaluation and classification mechanisms
• Remedies, backup-restrore and patching in case of security incidents

Cristian Șerban, Cyber Architect arobs
Rust Language Security – Best practices
• Features review
• How does Rust prevent buffer overflow, integer overflow, memory corruption and others
• It guarantees complete memory safety

Securing Data Demo
Alin Oprea, Junior Security Engineer arobs
Andrei Gherasim, Junior Security Engineer arobs
Ioana Oltean, Junior Security Engineer arobs
Adelina Dumitraș, Junior Security Engineer arobs

name: Secure Code Warrior CTF
description:
Secure Code Warrior Tournament + OWASP Columbus

When: October 28th, 12:00PM ET
October 30th, 5:00PM ET

Secure Code Warrior brings you a defensive security-based tournament from a developer's perspective. The tournament allows you to test your skill against the other participants in a series of vulnerable code challenges that ask you to identify a problem, locate insecure code, and fix a vulnerability. You don’t need extensive programming knowledge as this will be a great way to learn the foundations and intermediates of leveraging code that is not only functional but is also secure.

You can find the tournament step-by-step guide here: https://youtu.be/o8XhKK_eOOs

The tournament is run virtually so you can join through your laptop from the most convenient location and time. It should take only a few hours, drop-in as you see fit during the duration of the event to complete all the challenges and win prizes!

Instructions for playing:
1) Register for the Secure Code Warrior platform here: https://discover.securecodewarrior.com/OWASPColumbus.html
2) Check your email for the confirmation and access the unique link to create your profile.
3) Once logged in: click “Tournaments”
4) Join the OWASP Columbus Secure Coding Tournament

The Secure Code Warrior platform will be open before and after the tournament, so feel free to practice in the “Training” tab.

Monitor the live leaderboard to see how you're performing!

name: OWASP October Meeting
description:
Title:

Financial-grade API (FAPI)

Description:

Financial-grade API (FAPI) is a security framework devised by the OpenID foundation for securely using APIs specifically in the finance industry. The framework introduces more stringent security controls and strengthens the existing OAuth2 and OpenID Connect specifications. In this session Vinod will discuss various aspects of the framework and how they will address specific weaknesses in the traditional OAuth flows.

Bio:

Vinod Kannan is a seasoned cybersecurity professional with over 19 years of experience in cybersecurity with special interest in DevSecOps, Identity and Access Management, and Application Security. He has currently taken up the role as a Principal Consultant with Synopsys in its Software Integrity Group (SIG) and is focusing on managed security services offerings. Prior to this he has worked with Ernst & Young and HPE and various financial services firms such as JPMC and Bank of America. He is passionate in learning about new developments in the cybersecurity space that enables him in presenting the right solutions to clients.

name: OWASP Monthly Online meeting
description: The OWASP Foundation came online on December 1st, 2001 it was established as a not-for-profit charitable organization in the United States on April 21, 2004, to ensure the ongoing availability and support for our work at OWASP. OWASP is an international organization and the OWASP Foundation supports OWASP efforts around the world. OWASP is an open community dedicated to enabling organizations to conceive, develop, acquire, operate, and maintain applications that can be trusted. All of the OWASP tools, documents, forums, and chapters are free and open to anyone interested in improving application security. We advocate approaching application security as a people, process, and technology problem because the most effective approaches to application security include improvements in all of these areas. We can be found at www.owasp.org.

name: Open Web App Security Project - Kansas City Chapter Monthly Meeting
description:
Meetings of the Kansas City chapter of the Open Web Application Security Project are held at 6:00pm on the fourth MONDAY of each month, usually at the Kauffman Foundation Conference Center at 4801 Rockhill Rd, Kansas City, MO. Attendance is open to everyone - membership is not required (though we invite you to join the global OWASP organization and list our chapter as your home chapter)! RSVPs are not required - we don't track membership - but it's definitely helpful for planning!

Watch this space for more specific meeting details closer to the meeting date!

name: Hybrid Event! 2021 OWASP Top 10: What's New?
description:
Join the OWASP LV at the Tech Alley in person or virtual! (Link post registration)

Tech Alley Meetup Link: https://www.meetup.com/tech-alley/events/278983744/

Join OWASP Vegas for a look at the latest changes to the infamous OWASP Top 10. there are three new categories, four categories with naming and scoping changes, and some consolidation in the Top 10 for 2021. We will be holding an open discussion forum as we walk through each, and share how it may affect us. Whether you are a seasoned AppSec ninja or just interested, it will be informative and fun for everyone!

name: OWASP LA Monthly Virtual Meeting - OCT 27, 2021
description:
Come join us as we hear the monthly presentation by Aaron Guzman, Head of Product & Application Security with Cisco Meraki

TOPIC: OWASP & CSA IoT: Impacting Medical Security

ABSTRACT: The Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) IoT Project is designed to help manufacturers, developers, and consumers better understand the security issues associated with the Internet of Things as well as enable users in any context to make better security decisions when building, deploying, or assessing IoT technologies. Similarly, CSA's IoT Working group is dedicated to understanding IoT deployments and defining actionable guidance to secure ecosystems. Their efforts are often used to develop medical security guidelines for developers and manufacturers alike but also to influence IoT security assessment methodologies for later use on commercial IoT certification schemes. This session will provide insights into current project initiatives, including those that directly impact medical devices and how you can save lives by getting involved.

BIO: Aaron Guzman is a published author and a technical reviewer for several security books. He is the Head of Product & Application Security with Cisco Meraki where he focuses on building security into enterprise IoT products and crafting designs that keep users safe from compromise. Aaron spearheads many open-source initiatives, raising awareness about IoT hacking and proactive defensive strategies under OWASP’s IoT and Embedded Application Security projects. A co-chair of Cloud Security Alliance’s IoT Working Group, he has extensive public speaking experience delivering conference presentations, training, and workshops globally. Follow Aaron on Twitter @scriptingxss.

Meeting info will be available on meetup - BE SURE TO RSVP to access the link

ATTENTION SPONSORS: YOUR NAME COULD BE HERE
Check out sponsorship opportunities here
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/owasp-los-angeles-chapter-meeting-sponsorship-tickets-30572600471

name: OWASP Luxembourg Chapter - Meeting#2 - OWASP Top 10:2021 Overview
description:
Description of the talk:
Learn about the new OWASP Top 10:2021 that was released in September, 2021. This talk will walk through the process we used to build the new Top 10 and provide a brief overview of each of the risk categories in this updated list. Hear how the OWASP Top 10:2021 can fit into your organization and provide a baseline for secure development.

About the speaker:
Brian Glas, OWASP Top Ten Leader | Assistant Professor Of Computer Science, Union University Brian has over 20 years of experience in various roles in IT and over a decade and a half of that in application development and security. His day job is serving as an Assistant Professor teaching a full load of Computer Science and Cybersecurity classes at Union University. He helped build FedEx's AppSec team, worked on the Trustworthy Computing team at Microsoft, consulted on software security for years, and served as a project lead and active contributor for SAMM v1.1-2.0+ and OWASP Top 10 2017 and 2021. Brian is a contributor to the RABET-V Pilot Program. He holds several Cybersecurity and IT certifications and is currently working on his Doctor of Computer Science in Cybersecurity and Information Assurance.

Who should attend?
Both existing OWASP members and people unfamiliar with OWASP. Information security practitioners of all levels, IT professionals, and business leaders. Developers, development managers, product owners, QA professionals, program managers, and anyone involved in building software, etc.

name: CyberNight
description:
V okviru tekmovanja se bodo udeleženci soočili z reševanjem različnih varnostnih izzivov in si prislužili nova znanja, kot so kriptografija, obratno inženirstvo ... Izzivi bodo zapleteni, vendar primerni za igralce vseh ravni – od veteranov do tistih, za katere je ta CTF prvi, saj številni izzivi ne zahtevajo programskega znanja in so preprosto stvar kreativnega razmišljanja ter sposobnosti reševanja problemov.

Zmagovalec dogodka bo tekmovalec, ki si bo z rešenimi izzivi priboril največje število točk.

Upamo, da se nam pridružite. Za udeležbo na dogodku je obvezna prijava na Eventbrite.

Srečen lov!

name: October 2021 OWASP Chapter Netherlands Meetup
description:
19:00 - 19:15 Welcome
19:15 - 20:00 Our Secrets Management Journey: From Code to Vault by Jeroen Willemsen
20:00 - 20:15 Break
20:15 - 21:00 Doing Security in DevOps, the right way! by Irfaan Santoe

Our Secrets Management Journey: From Code to Vault

So you have an access key that you need to store somewhere. Maybe it is better not to put it in your code, nor in your container. But what about Kubernetes? What about a custom secrets storage solution? Of course, we tried many, sometimes funny, things to get our secrets secured. And luckily we ended up with a combination of safe methods, with Vault at its core. Want to know more? Join us, as we will go through various examples and their challenges!

Jeroen Willemsen is a Principal Security Architect at Xebia and a jack of all trades in security. He loves to develop new software, set up DevSecOps support tooling, and help companies with security programs. He enjoys sharing knowledge, which is why he published articles, blogs and gave trainings and talks about various subjects.

Doing Security in DevOps, the right way!

Automation is not DevSecOps, but without automation there is no DevSecOps! Secret management, SAST, DAST, Pen Testing, Container Security, Secure Config Management etc. are about automating security. But let me ask you, can one reach nirvana in securing DevOps with solely automation? This talk will address ALL dimensions required for doing security in DevOps, so we get it right!

Irfaan Santoe is a Global Security Director at Wolters Kluwer advising the Business & IT on the information security ambition & implementation. Prior to Wolters Kluwer, Irfaan was the Global Head of Security Engineering at ABN AMRO bank and lead the security implementation of ABN AMRO’s IT transformation towards DevOps. This transformation program is set to uplift more than 500+ Dev-teams to become DevOps and increasing security without breaking DevOps! Irfaan is a Master in Computer Science (a programmer by heart) and is fascinated by the Inner Science of Yoga & Meditation.

The YouTube link will be added to this page.

name: (Alert Level 1 permitting) The new OWASP Top 10 Web Application Security Risks

name: The beauty of runtime AppSec done right
description:
Speaker: Daniel Blazquez, Technical Product Marketing Lead, Hdiv Security

Topic: The beauty of runtime AppSec done right

Live stream: https://www.twitch.tv/owaspoc

Abstract:
Traditionally, application security practices oscillate between static activities (code scans, code reviews, threat modeling, etc.) and runtime activities (penetration testing, scanners, and WAFs). Static activities have context and depth, but lack visibility on the true behavior of the software. On the other hand, runtime activities have no direct access to the internals of the application because they follow an external approach.

DevOps teams are demanding a more complete picture of the security of the applications, combining static and dynamic activities. In this practical talk, I want to propose a new approach based on runtime observability, that provides not only vulnerabilities and attacks, but also app deployment intelligence, sensitive data visibility, and API discovery capabilities.

Speaker Bio:
Daniel Blazquez leads the technical marketing and developer advocacy practice at Hdiv Security, a VC-funded application security company focused on application security automation. As an ex-Java programmer and recovering corporate strategy professional, Daniel brings a holistic view to the S-SDLC practice: from coding to product management, all the way to growth strategy. His education includes a Computer Science master's and undergrad, and an MBA at UCLA Anderson.

Our meeting sponsor, Shiftleft, will provide a $40 Amazon gift card to all attendees who fill out our survey during the meeting. The URL for the survey will be given out during the meeting.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NOTE: Due to the continuing health concerns relating to the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), we will be meeting virtually until further notice.

name: OWASPOttawa October 2021: CISSP: Not just for squares
description:
Special Notice:

Due to the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) pandemic our events will continue online on our YouTube channel.

Subscribe to our YouTube channel, set a reminder and you’ll get a notification as soon as we go live!

We will post information here and on all our other medias (email, twitter etc.) as we are closer to the date.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tBdfEITSQNQ

7:00 PM EDT Technical Talks

1. Announcements

2. CISSP: Not just for squares

Abstract:
"On what type of fire would you use a Class C extinguisher?" "What is the difference between SLE and ARO?" ...Are you still awake?

These may be fine questions to ponder if you are a CISO putting together the DRP, agonizing over MTD and RTO. But what if you are a pentester or a security researcher, and you only care about kill chains and exfil channels?

I embarked on a CISSP journey with hesitation, but can now confidently say that it was time well spent. In this talk I outline my reasons for why I think CISSP is a worthwhile pursuit even for the hardcore red-teamer.

Bio:
Dmitriy Beryoza - Senior Security Researcher, Vectra AI
Dmitriy is a Senior Security Researcher at Vectra AI. He spent over 25 years of his life building software before realizing that breaking it is much more fun. Dmitriy is passionate about all things security, with particular interest in reverse engineering, binary exploitation, secure software development, and CTF competitions.

name: OWASP Meetup - CTF
description:
Capture the Flag (CTF) is a computer security competition. CTF contests are usually designed to serve as an educational exercise to give participants experience in securing a machine, as well as conducting and reacting to the sort of attacks found in the real world. Reverse-engineering, network sniffing, protocol analysis, system administration, programming, and cryptanalysis.

* This will be an open CTF which means this is open book. You may use any tool or internet accessible resource: Burpsuite, IDE, Metasploit, etc.

* Work in single or 2 person teams

* Be the person/team with the most challenges completed to win (time will determine a tie)

This CTF will run from October 18th-21st.
* October 18th Kickoff @ 7PM
* October 21st Finish & Demo @ 7PM

name: Monthly Meeting
description: Monthly OWASP meeting

description:
Hello All,

Come and join your fellow security practitioners at an informal virtual networking event on Friday October 8th, 2021 at noon. We will discuss upcoming plans for the Seattle Chapter, OWASP news & topics, and have an open forum discussion on what you, the members, would like to focus on in the coming months.

Thanks,

OWASP Seattle Leadership

name: Zero Trust Identity-Based Micro-segmentation (SPIFFE) & Secure Software Factory
description:
With the significant increased adoption in cloud-native technologies and against the backdrop of supply chain attacks (Solarwinds hack), what can all of us do to ensure what we build and deploy to Production is indeed secure? In this session, Nathan Aw will expound on the need for a Secure Software Factory (SSF), share some useful cloud-native security checklists and finally demo some security and compliance tools that can help to secure our cloud-native supply chain.

Speaker: Nathan Aw
A hands-on microservices developer turned AppSec architect and practitioner, Nathan Aw unyielding passion lies in building and deploying secure and scalable software that can run anywhere. Through the actual hands-on setup of a Secure Software Factory (SSF), Nathan understands intimately the importance of setting up a first-class secure software factory that is able to quickly deliver trusted and secure digital services to its customers. More on Nathan can be found at https://sg.linkedin.com/in/awnathan

name: Owasp Stockholm DevOps and security & Benefits of Cloud Thinking
description:
Welcome to a OWASP Stockholm event!

Finally we can meet IRL again and we will fire off with a Secure Development event hosted by Omegapoint at their new office site.

Location: Jakobsbergsgatan 24, Auditorium.
Time: October 21, 17.00 – 20.00
Lighter food & drinks will be served. The talks will begin at 17.30.

Session 1. DevOps and security
A presentation of a development lifecycle inspired by the DevOps loop with activities related to modern development and security with a discussion at the end.

Bio
Mats Persson, Consultant @ Omegapoint, passionate about Secure Development, Modern Ways of Working and Security in the Cloud

Session 2. Benefits of Cloud Thinking
Are Advanced Persistent Threats (APT) becoming the new normal? Should we get used to businesses getting pawned and having sensitive data leaked? Absolutely not! In this talk, we will present how designs often used in the cloud not only reduces risk of APTs, but also improve overall quality of your application – regardless if you’re running in the cloud or not.

Bio
Daniel Deogun & Dan Bergh Johnsson are authors of the book Secure by Design and have collectively been working with security and development for several decades. They are developers at heart and understand that security is often a side-concern. They’ve also evolved work habits that enable them to develop systems in a way that promotes security while focusing on high-quality design habits – something that’s easier for developers to keep in mind during their daily work. Both are established international speakers and often present at conferences on topics regarding high-quality development and security.

name: Application Security best practices
description:
Trends, such as "Everything as Code", moving to the Cloud and zero-trust do confirm that application security is already enormously important today. The fact that new data breaches, security vulnerabilities, ransomware and physical impacts of cyber-attacks are published daily in the news underlines the fact even more.

This talk explains why it is crucial to have security skills in every IT engineering team and why you cannot solely rely on a centralized security department - especially not in the agile world. Next to personal skills, this talk focuses on security best practices in software development. The speaker will highlight topics such as automated security testing methods and give recommendations on invaluable manual periodic security assessments.

This presentation is based on the speaker's personal experience and includes many learning's and tips from throughout his career. For example, how-to decide where it is absolutely necessary to invest 100% security effort and where the 80/20 principle is more than enough. Or also, why it is crucial to have a security baseline established, before thinking about a Bug-Bounty program.

About Manuel Cianci
Manuel has been a security enthusiast forever. Manuel started his technical security journey when he was 16 years old. His professional security career started some years later as a Security Software Engineer. In order to learn as many technical basics as possible, Manuel worked within different Security Software Engineering positions for more than eight years. Afterwards, he moved to a role as Security Engineer and Security Consultant.

For the last three years, Manuel was managing and leading the Security Delivery team of Swisscom. Manuel and his team were responsible for security engineering, consulting, and coaching services for the entire company. During his time at Swisscom, Manuel has been working on many subject areas in the security field. Introducing DevSecOps at Swisscom was one of his main achievements.

Just recently, Manuel decided to join cy//ective (cyllective AG) as Managing Partner. cy//ective is a Swiss IT security company, specialized in holistic security services.

name: Sydney OWASP Night -  Interview Tips & Tricks
description:
Say welcome to our guest Mon Siv who wants to help you become more confident in yourself when you next interview for a job, whether it’s in cybersecurity or in any other industry. His tips and tricks will ensure you establish the right skills to understand the interview process, what’s expected of yourself, and how to be ready to smash your goals.

Her top tips are:
Having the right mindset - Focus on the things you can control.
Research and preparation - The role and audience you will be presenting to.
Etiquette - Do’s and don’ts in an interview.

Mon Siv has spent 15 years working in the recruitment industry, recently moving to a new role with Fortian to help build and mature their internal recruitment function on their growth journey.

He has also worked in the agency world, specialising in the cybersecurity domain, helping candidates at various levels navigate through the recruitment process to secure their next role on their career path.

name: OWASP Sydney - Fun with Hack the Box
description:
Please join us to play/train in Hack The Box (HTB), what you need is a Hack the Box account, free is cool, join us in discord (link https://discord.com/invite/uAWze2B) - FC-Announcements-Voice Channel, please ensure, after registration in Discord you go to the Bot and accept the Code of Conduct, otherwise, you won't be able to access the channels.

There is no format to this night, we just want to get together to have some fun playing some battlegrounds, doing some of the machines or challenges; having fun overall!

name: Taller: #TechTalk: API con NestJS y las Maravillas de TS
description: Taller: API con NestJS y las Maravillas de TS

name: Speaker TBA - Contact us if interested
description: TBA

name: Life, the Universe and everything Application Security
description:
It is OWASP Vancouver's annual panel conversation and this time it will be an Ask Me Anything... about Application Security. We want YOU to pick what we should talk about, what is on YOUR mind?

We can talk about:
- Supply chain attacks in the AppSec space
- Web application safety of vaccine passports
- Application Security tooling
- Security career questions

The topics are endless and the panelists are ready!

name: Demystifying Mobile Security With a COVID App
description:
In this episode, we will unveil the mystery of mobile security. The presentation will be in parts. We will discuss the OWASP Mobile Top 10, and then delve into components of an Android application, sample tools for mobile security. Next, we'll look at core files in an Android app followed by the results of reverse engineering a COVID app. Finally, we will end the presentation with the next steps to continue learning mobile security.

JASMINE JACKSON
Jasmine shares her passion for Information Security by presenting and teaching workshops with over ten years of Information Security experience. She is currently the Jeopardy-style Capture The Flag (CTF) Coach for the inaugural US Cyber Games. She is also an Adjunct Professor at Drexel University and City University of Seattle with additional courses with Cybrary. Finally, Jasmine has certifications in Secure Programming, Web Application Pentesting, and Cloud Security. Jasmine has a master’s degree in Computer Science and a Graduate Certificate in Information Security and Privacy from the University of North Carolina, Charlotte. Currently, she works as a Senior Application Security Engineer for a Fortune 500 company. She has presented her work domestically and internationally for such conferences - The Diana Initiative, Bugcrowd, Blacks in Cybersecurity, and NotPinkCon in topics of Mobile Security, and Web Application Security.

In her spare time, she likes to stay up to date on security vulnerabilities by completing capture the flag write-ups on her blog, vulnerability disclosures, and YouTube channel. Besides Jasmine’s passion for teaching, she also has a passion for educating the next generation of Information Security professionals by volunteering with organizations - Biohacking Village, BlackGirlsHack, Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP), and Women’s Society of Cyberjutsu.

Reach out to her on all social media platforms - @thefluffy007.

name: How to Analyze Code for Vulnerabilities using Joern
description:
Code analysis is the process of analyzing the code of a program to find security vulnerabilities. It is the most effective way to identify many types of security issues, from injection vulnerabilities to issues like leaked secrets and vulnerable dependencies. But the process of manually analyzing code for vulnerabilities can be very time-consuming. Is there a better way to do this?

In this talk, Vickie and Suchakra will demonstrate how to use open-sourced code analysis tool Joern to make code analysis more efficient. How do you effectively trace user input in code? How can you efficiently link bug sources to sensitive sink functions? This is the second edition of How to analyze code for vulnerabilities (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A8CNysN-lOM), this time, we’ll talk about how to do it efficiently using Joern.

VICKIE LI
Vickie Li is the resident developer evangelist at ShiftLeft. She is an experienced web developer with an avid interest in security research. She can be found on https://vickieli.dev, where she blogs about security news, techniques, and her latest bug bounty findings. She also hosts “Security Simplified”, a developer education series focusing on web security: https://www.youtube.com/c/vickielidev.

SUCHAKRA SHARMA
Suchakra Sharma is Staff Scientist at ShiftLeft Inc. where he builds code analysis tools and hunts security bugs. He completed his Ph.D. in Computer Engineering from Polytechnique Montréal where he worked on eBPF technology and hardware-assisted tracing techniques for OS analysis. As part of his research, he also developed one of the first hardware-trace based virtual machine analysis techniques. He has delivered talks and trainings at venues such as RSA, USENIX LISA, SCALE, Papers We Love, Tracing Summit, etc. When not playing with computers, he hikes and writes poems.
